raw_text:
Row threatens Hendrix museum plan
 
 Proposals to open a museum dedicated to Jimi Hendrix are flailing because of a row over the home of his late father.
 
 The run-down house in Seattle has already been moved wholesale once and local authorities are now demanding it be moved to another site. Hendrix supporters hoped to turn the home into a museum for the guitarist. "The mayor is going to go down as the mayor who destroyed Jimi Hendrix's house," said Ray Rae Marshall of the James Marshall Hendrix Foundation. The foundation moved the building, in which Al Hendrix lived between 1953 and 1956, when the land it was built on was to be developed for housing in 2002. Now the City of Seattle wants its new plot to be used for development, giving a deadline of 22 February for the home to be moved. Mr Goldman said the authority had promised the house could remain on its new site and be turned into a memorial and community centre. Seattle officials said no such deal had been offered.
 
 "We never said, 'You can own this property,'" said John Franklin, chief of its operations department. "From our perspective, it was a temporary situation. We have not threatened to demolish the house. We've simply asked that they have to move it." Now Mr Goldman is calling for the authority to pay to move the building to Seattle's central district, where Hendrix grew up. Janie Hendrix, the guitarist's stepsister, said the family were still hoping the guitarist would be honoured by having a road named after him. "That's something my father really wanted to see," she said. "It would be nice if we didn't have to fight for everything to get it." Hendrix was widely considered one of the most important guitarists of his time. He died of drug overdose in 1970 at the age of 27.
llama3.2:1b: A proposal to open a museum dedicated to Jimi Hendrix is stalled due to a dispute over the ownership and relocation of his late father's home in Seattle. The city has demanded that the property be moved to another site, despite previous agreements stating it could remain on its new location. The James Marshall Hendrix Foundation opposes this move, arguing that it was made as a temporary solution and not an ownership issue.
llama3.2:3b: A museum plan for Jimi Hendrix is stalled due to a dispute over the location of his late father's home, which has already been moved once and now faces being relocated again by local authorities who claim it is needed for development. The foundation behind the museum proposal had promised that the building could remain on its new site as a memorial and community center, but Seattle officials say no such deal was made.
gemma2:2b: A proposed Jimi Hendrix museum is facing delays due to a dispute over the location of his father's former home, which the city wants to redevelop.  The Foundation moved the house previously, but Seattle authorities are now demanding its relocation to a new site by February 22nd, despite promises of turning it into a memorial and community center. The family is still pushing for the name of Hendrix to be honored through road designation.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Seattle authorities are fighting a row over Jimi Hendrix's home and plans for a museum dedicated to him, as local authorities demanded it be moved to another site after an earlier move was rejected. The foundation moved the house where Al Hendrix lived between 1953 and 1956, which is now being developed in Seattle for housing. "We never said, 'You can own this property,'" said John Franklin, chief of its operations department.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Jimi Hendrix Museum proposal faces opposition due to a dispute over moving Al Hendrix's father's home, which has already been relocated twice, from Seattle. Authorities now demand it be moved to another site before approving development on the land where it was originally built in 2002 for housing.
qwen2.5:3b: Row over Jimi Hendrix's home threatens museum plans, with local authorities demanding its relocation to a new site set by February 22nd. The James Marshall Hendrix Foundation initially moved the house for development but now hopes to convert it into a memorial and community center in Seattle’s central district. City officials deny threatening demolition and propose paying for relocation instead of keeping the house on its current site, sparking conflict between supporters hoping for a museum and preservation. Janie Hendrix, Jimi's stepsister, emphasizes her father's desire to have a road named after him.

smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise and preserves key ideas, including:

1. The proposal to open a museum dedicated to Jimi Hendrix was flailing because of a row over the home of his late father.
2. The run-down house in Seattle had already been moved once and local authorities are now demanding it be moved to another site.
3. Hendrix supporters hoped to turn the home into a museum for the guitarist.
4. The mayor is going to go down as the mayor who destroyed Jimi Hendrix's house, which would have made him a hero if he had lived longer.
5. Ray Rae Marshall of the James Marshall Hendrix Foundation said that the city wanted its new plot to be used for development and turned into a memorial and community centre.
6. The city is demanding that the home be moved to another site, which would have been the city's property if it had not been sold.
7. Seattle officials are now threatening to demolish the house unless it is moved to their new plot.
8. The authority has promised to move the building to a different site and turn it into a memorial and community centre.
9. The city wants to pay for the home to be moved, but not necessarily demolished.
10. John Franklin, the operations director of the City of Seattle's Department of Transportation, said that they had offered to help with the move, but that the authority would have to pay for it.
11. The authority is concerned about the impact on Jimi Hendrix's legacy if the home were not moved to a new site.
12. The city is still working out its plans and may need to negotiate with the city council or other authorities before making any decisions.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about Jimi Hendrix's home and proposals to turn it into a museum. Let me read through the content again to understand the key points.

So, first, there's a conflict between Hendrix supporters and some local authorities over a house in Seattle called the Hendrix Foundation. The house is a run-down old place for Al Hendrix and his family. They've been moved before, but now they're asking the city to move it again because of a new plan.

The city wants the building to be moved by February 22nd, and they want the mayor and others to have the authority to do so without destroying the house. But someone mentioned that the mayor is going to claim his office because he destroyed the house, which might make it harder for the city.

Hendrix himself, named Ray Rae Marshall, stated that this was a temporary situation and didn't threaten the property. Instead, he asked the authorities to move the building so Hendrix can have his museum. The family wants it named after him.

Now, someone suggested paying for the house to be moved by Janie Hendrix, their stepsister. She's hoping to see a road named after her father and that she doesn't have to fight everything to get the honor.

Hendrix was a huge figure in music, died in 1970 at 27 from overdose. The proposals are causing some tension with his family, so they're trying to turn the house into a museum or memorial.

I need to make sure I include all these points: the conflict between Hendrix supporters and the city, the reasons for moving the building (the new development plan in 2002, moving it now), the mayor's statement about destroying the property, the family's desire for the museum named after their father, the idea of a payment to move the house, and Hendrix's legacy as one of the greatest guitarists.

I also need to note that the city hasn't offered any deal yet. The proposal is still pending approval from the authorities.
</think>

The conflict between Jimi Hendrix supporters and Seattle officials over Al Hendrix's run-down home in Seattle has been ongoing. The house, built in 1953-1956 by Al Hendrix and his family, was moved to another site once before. The city of Seattle is now requesting the move to a new development location for development purposes with a deadline set for moving on February 22nd. The mayor's office is concerned that the move would require destruction of the property, but instead, they are asking the authority to allow the house to be moved without immediate demolition.

Hendrix himself, Ray Rae Marshall, emphasized that this was a temporary situation and did not threaten the property. He expressed hope for the city to move it so Hendrix can have his museum. The family, led by their stepsister Janie Hendrix, seek the honor of naming the road after their father, reflecting his importance in music.

Hendrix, known as one of the greatest guitarists, died in 1970 from an overdose. Despite the proposals, no deal has been offered yet for the house to be moved or a memorial named after him. The city remains unfulfilled in its request for the move and payment to clear the property.
tinyllama:1.1b: Following a row between authorities and Jimi Hendrix's support group, the home where he lived with his late father has been threatened with demolition as Seaxton tries to develop the site for housing in 2002. Local officials have been demanding that the house be moved to the new plot, but the James Marshall Hendrix Foundation is now calling for compensation and a permanent memorial on the site of their original property. Despite promising not to demolish the house, Seaxton officials say they cannot offer any guarantees about its future ownership, leaving the foundation to seek a move to another location. The family's efforts for Jimi Hendrix's honouring have yet to be fulfilled, as his legendary status continues to endure.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The proposal to build a museum dedicated to Jimi Hendrix is facing significant hurdles due to disagreements about the home of his late father, which has been relocated wholesale and requires the local authorities to approve its move again. The James Marshall Hendrix Foundation had hoped to turn the house into a museum for the guitarist, but city officials are now demanding that the property be moved to another site, with Al Hendrix's residence between 1953 and 1956 at the heart of the issue. Despite assurances by local authorities not to demolish the house, Seattle officials have been insistent on moving it to a new site for development purposes. The situation has left the family of Hendrix stunned and disappointed as they continue to hope that his legacy will be honored through a proper memorial and community center.
phi:2.7b: The plans to open a museum dedicated to Jimi Hendrix are falling through due to a dispute over the home of his late father, who lived there between 1915 and 1917. The city of Seattle has moved the house once before for development purposes and now demands it be moved again. Supporters of Hendrix are calling for the city to pay for the house's relocation to a central district where he grew up.
orca-mini:3b: A row is preventing the move of Jimi Hendrix's family home, which has already been moved twice and is now required to be moved to a different site. The house is owned by Seattle authorities who have given a deadline of February 22nd for it to be moved. The family is calling for the building to be moved to a central district where Hendrix grew up, and wants a road named after him.
hermes3:3b: Hendrix museum row over father's house move

Meanwhile, Janie Hendrix, the guitarist's stepsister, hopes for a road to be named after him as he considered it one of the most important guitarists of his time, passing away in 1970 at age 27 due to a drug overdose.

The city denies offering a deal to keep the house as a memorial and community center. Foundation officials, including Ray Rae Marshall, are advocating for the city's payment to cover relocation costs to Seattle's central district.
